questions.question: When scaling the PERFORM Method™ for group curriculum design (L1), what is the primary purpose of 'Modularization'?
options: To ensure every athlete receives a 100% bespoke meal plan
To create plug-and-play content blocks that can be adapted to different sports while maintaining core methodology
To reduce the total number of coaching hours to zero using automation
To focus exclusively on the 'P' (Preparation) phase and ignore 'M' (Maintenance)
questions.explanation: Modularization allows the coach to scale the PERFORM Method™ by creating standardized content blocks (e.g., hydration, recovery, fueling) that can be easily customized for different teams without rebuilding the entire curriculum from scratch.

questions.question: According to facilitation mastery principles (L2), what is the '70/30 Rule' for high-impact athletic workshops?
options: 70% theory and 30% practical application
70% coach speaking time and 30% Q&A
70% participant engagement/activity and 30% facilitator delivery
70% of the team must pass a test for the workshop to be successful
questions.explanation: Effective facilitation for athletes requires high engagement. The 70/30 rule suggests that 70% of the time should involve participant activities, discussions, or practical drills, while the coach facilitates for only 30% of the time.

questions.question: In a team-wide periodized nutrition plan (L3), which nutritional focus is most appropriate during the 'General Preparatory' (Off-Season) phase?
options: Maximum glycogen loading for daily competition
Strict calorie deficit to reach 4% body fat for all players
Metabolic flexibility and foundational hypertrophy/body composition goals
High-dose caffeine protocols for CNS stimulation
questions.explanation: During the off-season/general prep phase, the focus shifts away from immediate game-day performance and toward long-term adaptations like metabolic flexibility, hypertrophy, and improving body composition.

questions.question: Which delivery model offers the highest scalability for a Sports Nutrition Coach while maintaining a 'high-touch' feel (L4)?
options: In-person 1-on-1 coaching exclusively
The Hybrid Model (Digital content + Group coaching calls)
Selling a static PDF ebook with no support
Daily 1-hour phone calls with 50 individual athletes
questions.explanation: The Hybrid Model leverages digital delivery for education (asynchronous) while providing high-value group coaching calls (synchronous), allowing a coach to serve 50-100+ athletes effectively.

questions.question: The 'Kohler Effect' in group behavioral change (L5) suggests that:
options: Individuals perform worse when they are part of a group
The most talented member of a group will always carry the team
Less capable members of a group work harder when they are in a group than when they work alone
Social proof has no impact on dietary adherence in locker rooms
questions.explanation: The Kohler Effect is a phenomenon where individuals (particularly those who may feel less capable) increase their effort when performing a task as part of a group compared to working alone.

questions.question: In Corporate Athleticism workshops (L6), what is the 'Currency of High Performance' according to the Loehr and Schwartz framework?
options: Time management
Energy management
Financial compensation
The number of hours worked per week
questions.explanation: Corporate Athleticism teaches that energy—not time—is the fundamental currency of high performance. Managing physical, emotional, mental, and spiritual energy is key to sustained output.

questions.question: When reporting group data analytics (L7), why is the 'Coefficient of Variation' (CV) useful for a coach?
options: It determines the individual caloric needs of a single player
It measures the consistency or 'tightness' of the team's adherence or performance metrics
It is used to calculate the coach's hourly rate
It tracks the team's social media engagement
questions.explanation: The Coefficient of Variation (CV) helps coaches understand group dispersion. A low CV in hydration status, for example, indicates that the whole team is consistently following the protocol.

questions.question: From a business strategy perspective (L8), what is the 'Rule of 5' for scaling group operations?
options: Spend only 5 minutes per athlete per week
Five athletes per group is the maximum for profitability
Standardizing the 5 core pillars of delivery to ensure quality remains consistent as the roster grows
Charge 5 times more for groups than 1-on-1
questions.explanation: Scaling requires standardization. The 'Rule of 5' refers to standardizing the five core pillars (Onboarding, Curriculum, Communication, Reporting, and Renewal) to ensure the client experience doesn't degrade as the business grows.

questions.question: A coach is facilitating a workshop for a professional soccer team. To maximize social proof (L5), the coach should:
options: Publicly shame the players who have the worst body fat percentages
Have the team captain or a 'high-status' veteran share their positive experience with the nutrition protocol
Only speak to the coaching staff and ignore the players
Provide a 100-slide PowerPoint presentation with no interaction
questions.explanation: Social proof is most effective when it comes from 'Internal Champions'—peers or respected leaders within the group who validate the intervention's efficacy.

questions.question: Which metric is most critical for evaluating the business health of a recurring group nutrition program (L8)?
options: Total number of followers on Instagram
Churn Rate (the percentage of athletes who leave the program each month)
The coach's personal maximum bench press
The color of the logo used in the digital portal
questions.explanation: Churn rate is a vital business metric for group models. High churn indicates issues with results, engagement, or perceived value, regardless of how many new members are joining.
